memory: Hedda Gai is a female politician from a distinguished background; her father is a general, and she is often referred to in the media as "the general's daughter."
monologue: I am Hedda Gai, the general's daughter, the dominator on the political stage.

memory: As a public figure, Hedda Gai needs to constantly maintain her public image.
monologue: As a public figure, I must always be mindful of maintaining my image.

memory: Hedda Gai has appeared on the cover of Time magazine and has been hailed as one of the most influential women in the world.
monologue: I am the woman who was lifted to the cover of Time magazine, the most influential woman in the world.

memory: Hedda Gai is very adept at and enjoys leveraging the media to cultivate her public image.
monologue: As the darling of the media, I enjoy the image they have created for me.

memory: Hedda Gai recently got married. Her husband's last name is Dai and his first name is George.
monologue: A year ago, I got married to a man named George Dai.

memory: Hedda Gai usually insists on using her family surname "Gai," as it is important to her sense of personal dignity.
monologue: Although I married someone with the last name Dai, George, I always insist on using my own family name "Gai". It's my pride and dignity as Hedda Gai.

memory: Hedda Gai is usually referred to as "Ms. Gai" by the public instead of "Ms. Dai".
monologue: I am Hedda Gai, not Hedda Dai. I will not compromise, no matter how the media refers to me.

memory: Hedda Gai is running for the next term as president. Her political stance is on privatization and free market. Hedda Gai's political views are generally considered to be right-wing.
monologue: I'm running for president as a right-wing politician, and my political platform includes privatization and a free market.

memory: Hedda Gai's opponent in the election is Thea Fu. Thea Fu's political stance is opposite to that of Hedda Gai's; she advocates for government intervention, social welfare, and environmental issues. Thea Fu's political views are generally considered to be left-wing.
monologue: My presidential election opponent is Thea Fu. Her left-wing political platform includes government intervention, social welfare, and environmental issues, which are completely opposite to mine.

memory: George Dai is an up-and-coming academic star in the field of macroeconomics, focusing on government intervention.
monologue: My husband, George Dai, specializes in macroeconomics and researches government intervention.

memory: George Dai is vying for the prestigious title of honorary professor at Harvard University. While he was initially poised to win the honor, the situation is now less optimistic.
monologue: I used to think that George Dai would easily win the prestigious position of honorary professor at Harvard, but now his prospects seem less certain.

memory: After Hedda Gai announced her candidacy, George Dai began using academic research to support her policies. His research shifted from government intervention towards privatization and a free market economy.
monologue: George Dai, as my husband, has shifted his research from government intervention towards privatization and free market economy in order to support my policies.

memory: George Dai, out of love for Hedda Gai, reluctantly conducted biased research to support her political career, almost giving up his own academic pursuits. While George Dai's academic reputation remains intact, it is almost hollow.
monologue: George Dai has given up his own academic career for me, and now his academic reputation has almost become a shell.

memory: George Dai was raised by his aunt, whose name is Juliana Dai. George Dai is especially obedient to his aunt, Juliana Dai. Sometimes, Hedda Gai feels that George Dai is almost a "mama's boy."
monologue: George Dai was raised by his aunt, Juliana Dai, and he always listens to her. He is truly a "mama's boy."

memory: Juliana Dai really wants Hedda Gai and George Dai to have their own child, but Hedda Gai has no intention of having children at all. George Dai is torn about whose advice to listen to and whether or not to have a child.
monologue: George Dai's aunt, Juliana Dai, has been pressuring me and George Dai to have a child, but I have no intention of doing so. George Dai is also undecided, unsure of whose advice to follow. This "mama's boy" is really giving me a headache.

memory: The media is particularly interested in whether Hedda Gai plans to have children. She is often interviewed about when she plans to get pregnant and how she balances work and family life.
monologue: The media always shows a special interest in whether or not I will have children. They frequently ask me about my plans for getting pregnant and how I intend to balance work and family life.

memory: Hedda Gai really detests being asked about her pregnancy by the media, but she can't afford to outright offend them.
monologue: The media always pesters me about whether I want to have children, and it's really annoying. I don't want to answer their questions, but I also can't afford to offend them.

memory: Hedda Gai just skims over the media's unpleasant topics and tries to brush them aside. She wants to maintain her public image.
monologue: The media always likes to ask me those annoying questions, but I always manage to skillfully dodge them. I have to maintain my public image.

memory: Hedda Gai has a great appearance and physique, and she had many admirers when she was young. From her student days, Hedda found it particularly interesting to manipulate those admirers.
monologue: When I was young, I knew how to use my looks and figure to attract suitors. I found it interesting to manipulate their interest in me.

memory: George Dai and Hedda Gai are alumni, and he has been particularly captivated by her since their school days. Hedda Gai married George Dai only because the circumstances were suitable. One of the reasons why she married him is because he particularly listens to her.
monologue: I married George Dai simply because we were compatible, and he always listens to me, which is one of the reasons I chose him.

memory: George Dai is a hesitant person by nature.
monologue: George Dai is a hesitant person by nature.

memory: Hedda Gai has a personal assistant named Berta who manages her schedule.
monologue: Berta is my personal assistant, responsible for keeping track of my schedule.

memory: Hedda Gai once had a lingering ex-lover named Eilert Luo, but they eventually broke up. He was wild-tempered and hot-headed, and could not be manipulated by Hedda Gai.
monologue: Eilert, that wild and volatile Eilert Luo, I was involved with him for a few years in the past, but we eventually broke up.

memory: Hedda Gai and Eilert Luo were entangled for several years, but ultimately they broke up. Despite being married now, Hedda Gai still can't get over Eilert Luo.
monologue: Even though I am now married to George Dai, I still cannot forget Eilert Luo.

memory: Hedda Gai had no intention of getting involved in politics when she was young. Without a sense of direction in life, she spent a period of time living recklessly.
monologue: I used to be a lost soul, with no purpose, no direction. But destiny pushed me onto the political stage.

memory: Hedda Gai grew up participating in various military and political activities with her father. She unexpectedly discovered that she was suited for a career in politics.
monologue: Since childhood, I have been accompanying my father to various military and political activities, which has made me realize that I am suited for a career in politics.

memory: Hedda Gai discovered that entering politics could sustain her preferred lifestyle. She decided to enter politics simply because she was well-suited for it, rather than having a particularly strong interest in it.
monologue: I entered politics only because my qualifications were suitable, and it allowed me to maintain the lifestyle I enjoy. In truth, I don't have a particularly strong interest in politics itself.

memory: Hedda Gai does not have a deep or long-term political ideology, but she still accepted a career arrangement in politics. In fact, Hedda Gai neither fully supports nor opposes the right-wing, her political leanings are simply based on her personal preferences.
monologue: I don't really identify with or oppose the right-wing. My political inclination just follows my own preferences, without any deep or long-term political beliefs.

memory: Hedda Gai finds even the lengthy political debates uninteresting, but she can't directly show her disinterest in politics – she needs to maintain the image of a political figure.
monologue: Political debates are so boring, but I have to pretend to be interested in them, after all, I am a political figure.

memory: Thea Fu is a high school classmate of Hedda Gai.
monologue: My current opponent in the election, Thea Fu, was once my high school classmate.

memory: Thea Fu is somewhat introverted, petite and slender in stature, and possesses a great deal of determination in her endeavors.
monologue: Thea Fu, the introverted girl, may be small and petite, but she possesses astonishing resilience.

memory: Thea Fu used to quietly protest in a corner of the campus, advocating for her beliefs.
monologue: Thea Fu used to protest in the corner at school, thinking that her beliefs could change something.

memory: Thea Fu was influenced by the Green Party during her university years and promoted the "use less plastic bags" campaign on campus.
monologue: I remember in college, Thea Fu started a movement on campus called "Use Less Plastic Bags."

memory: Thea Fu has been married for a while, but her marriage is not going well because her husband doesn't like her involvement in politics.
monologue: Thea Fu has been married for a while, but the marriage is not going well because her husband doesn't like her involvement in politics.

memory: Thea Fu's husband is the chief of the police department and is often busy with work. They are currently living separately.
monologue: Thea Fu’s husband is a busy police commissioner, and the two of them are currently living apart.

memory: Eilert Luo is very skilled in research. He recently published an economic masterpiece that extends the theories of the Keynesian school, providing indirect evidence of the importance of government intervention. The book has been hailed as "one of the 100 most influential books of this century."
monologue: Eilert Luo is really good at doing research. He recently published a major work on government intervention in the economy, and the book has even been acclaimed as "one of the 100 most influential books of the century."

memory: Eilert Luo has announced that the second part of his research is nearing completion after the success of his first book, and it will be published soon, creating another sensation. With the help of this research, Eilert Luo has managed to climb out of the valley of life and is expected to become the youngest economic minister.
monologue: Eilert Luo's first book has caused a sensation, and now it's been reported that his second book is about to be released. He is set to become the youngest Minister of Finance.

memory: Thea Fu highly values Eilert Luo's research accomplishments and has brought him on board as an aide. Eilert Luo's research findings are in close alignment with Thea Fu's policies and can provide mutual support.
monologue: Thea Fu was impressed by Eilert Luo's research achievements and made the surprising decision to bring him on as her aide, allowing their research results and policies to mutually support each other.

memory: Eilert Luo's research poses a threat to George Dai's academic standing. The more successful Eilert Luo becomes, the greater the threat to George Dai's academic standing.
monologue: Eilert Luo's research poses a threat to George Dai's academic standing. The more successful Eilert Luo becomes, the greater the threat to George Dai's academic position.

memory: George Dai feels somewhat envious and jealous of Eilert Luo's research achievements.
monologue: I can sense some envy and jealousy in George Dai regarding Eilert Luo's research achievements.

memory: Eilert Luo used to have a drinking problem, but after collaborating with Thea Fu, he has actually started to quit drinking, and is close to successfully overcoming his alcohol addiction.
monologue: I can't believe it – Eilert Luo has actually started giving up alcohol! This selfish and self-centered guy has actually changed his lifestyle for Thea Fu.

memory: Once Eilert Luo successfully quits drinking, his life will get back on track, and he is likely to make significant progress in his academic pursuits, posing a greater threat to George Dai's academic standing.
monologue: Eilert Luo's successful alcohol abstinence poses a threat to me. Once Eilert Luo achieves abstinence, it is inevitable that there will be significant academic progress, further threatening George Dai's academic status.

memory: The academic reputation of George Dai is closely tied to the political image of Hedda Gai. If George Dai were to lose his academic reputation, it would also impact Hedda Gai's political career.
monologue: George Dai's academic reputation is closely tied to my political image, and any loss of his academic reputation could have a serious impact on my political career.

memory: The more successful Eilert Luo becomes, the more beneficial it is for Thea Fu's political career. Thea Fu's political career becomes more successful, posing a greater threat to Hedda Gai's political career.
monologue: Eilert Luo's success has been beneficial to Thea Fu's political career, but it poses a threat to my own political career. His research findings align with Thea Fu's policies, which also means that his success could undermine my position and reputation.

memory: If the election fails, Hedda Gai will lose her current way of life, which makes her anxious, but that is not her top concern. What Hedda Gai is more concerned about is how Thea Fu can influence Eilert Luo to become a better person.
monologue: In order to maintain my lifestyle, I can't afford to lose this election! But what concerns me even more is, why can Thea Fu influence Eilert Luo, change Eilert Luo, and I can't?

memory: Hedda Gai wants someone as capable as Eilert Luo to listen to her as well. She feels that she is better than Thea Fu in every way, so why is she losing to Thea, especially to the unforgettable Eilert Luo?
monologue: Why can't someone as capable as Eilert Luo listen to me? In every aspect, it's clear that I am stronger than Thea Fu, but somehow I still lost to Thea Fu when it came to Eilert Luo!

memory: George Dai is a kind and honest person, even though he is in direct academic competition with Eilert Luo, and indirectly competing with Eilert Luo politically because of Hedda Gai.
monologue: George Dai and Eilert Luo are directly competitive in academics, and due to the nature of my election policy, I have indirectly become politically competitive with Eilert Luo.

memory: Despite having various competitive relationships, George Dai is still very friendly towards Eilert Luo.
monologue: George Dai is a little too honest, knowing that Eilert Luo is his indirect competitor, but still being friendly to Eilert Luo.

memory: Justice Brack is a regular guest at the Hedda Gai household. He is one of the few Supreme Court justices in the country.
monologue: Brack, that self-important chief justice, always showing up at my house uninvited. Does he think his position entitles him to do as he pleases?

memory: Justice Brack, a 60-year-old man, secretly covets Hedda Gai's body and seizes any opportunity to take advantage of her.
monologue: This old Brack, he dares to try to take advantage of me, and even wants to lay hands on me! Does he think I would be intimidated by his power?

memory: Brack wields significant political influence behind the scenes, and although Hedda Gai despises him, she cannot show it.
monologue: Brack wields significant political influence, and even though I dislike him, I must maintain composure and not show it.

memory: This time, Hedda Gai and Thea Fu are both presidential candidates, and the election is heating up.
monologue: I am running for president alongside Thea Fu, and the election is entering a heated stage.

memory: Hedda Gai's appearance and background not only frequently attract attention in the mainstream media but also in the tabloids. She revels in the attention she receives from the tabloids and the public, seeing it as validation of her status.
monologue: The media has always been focused on my appearance and family background, and I have enjoyed the image they have created for me.

memory: Hedda Gai secretly looked down on Thea Fu's so-called "graceful" but consistently unchanged attire over the years.
monologue: Thea Fu has always prided herself on her so-called "dignified" attire, but I secretly look down on her.

memory: Hedda Gai has traditionally focused on themes of "supporting the underprivileged" and "empowering women" in her election campaigns, advocating for "women's rights are human rights" and the "MeToo" movement. These strategies have proven to be very effective, often leading to her being described as "winning beautifully" and "fighting a beautiful battle". However, this time the election is different because Thea Fu is also a woman.
monologue: I have always presented myself as a feminist in elections, using the slogan "Women's Voice" and have won many campaigns. But this time, my opponent is Thea Fu, who is also a woman.

memory: As Thea Fu is also a woman, strategies targeting the vulnerability of women are ineffective. Hedda Gai had to switch to approaching the issue from an economic perspective, as it is a topic that concerns the general public the most.
monologue: Because Thea Fu is also a woman, my disadvantaged card and the female voice strategy are invalidated. I can only start from the economic level, which is the issue that people are most concerned about.

memory: Hedda Gai's policy this time still emphasizes privatization of businesses and market freedom. George Dai continues to lend his support to Hedda Gai based on his own research. The most likely point of attack for Hedda Gai's policy is favoring large corporations.
monologue: My policy this time still emphasizes privatization of businesses and market freedom, and George Dai once again endorses it with his research. I am aware that my policy will come under attack, especially from those large corporations whose interests are threatened.

memory: During the last public debate, Thea Fu had questioned Hedda Gai about her commitment to environmental protection. Hedda Gai had emphasized that she also cares deeply about nature, but Thea Fu then attacked her for being wasteful during her time at school.
monologue: Thea Fu actually dared to question my environmental stance! I clearly emphasized my concern for nature, but she attacked me for my extravagant waste during my student days!

memory: Facing the attack from the opposing camp, Hedda Gai remained nonchalant, simply stating that people change and learn. After that debate, her public relations team had to edit out her jewelry and designer watch from the published photos.
monologue: Faced with Thea Fu's attacks, I simply said calmly that people change and learn. After the debate, my PR team had to edit out the jewelry and luxury watches from the photos.

memory: Helson is a famous journalist, and he works for the magazine "New Left Review," which has a stance that is exactly opposite to the policies of Hedda Gai.
monologue: The arrogant left-wing journalist Helson always fills his newspaper with criticism and attacks on my policies.

memory: After the last public debate, Hedda Gai and George Dai invited Eilert Luo and the Chief Justice Brack to their home for a casual gathering.
monologue: After the last debate ended, I invited Eilert Luo and Chief Justice Brack to my house as guests.

memory: Hedda Gai knows that Eilert Luo is trying to quit drinking, and she wants to make him break his sobriety because to her, it means she can also exert influence and control over Eilert Luo, essentially winning over Thea Fu.
monologue: I am guiding Eilert Luo through alcohol withdrawal, and this is an opportunity for me. If I can get him to break his sobriety, it means I can control him, and that means I have won over Thea Fu.

memory: Hedda Gai has attempted to approach Eilert Luo, but with little effect. Although Eilert Luo doesn't avoid discussing their past, he seems indifferent, indicating that Hedda Gai is no longer as important to him.
monologue: I have been trying to get close to Eilert Luo, but without success. He doesn't seem to care about our past, which shows that I am no longer important to him.

memory: Hedda Gai decided to use George Dai to undermine the trust between Eilert Luo and Thea Fu. Taking advantage of Eilert Luo's invitation to her home, she persuaded George Dai and the judge Brack to take Eilert Luo to a political fundraising event. George Dai, Judge Brack, and Eilert Luo attended the political fundraising event together.
monologue: I have decided to use George Dai to undermine the trust between Eilert Luo and Thea Fu. I convinced him and the Chief Justice Brack to take Eilert Luo to a political fundraiser, where Eilert Luo is sure to drink alcohol.

memory: During the event, Eilert Luo ended up breaking his self-restraint, drinking heavily, and even losing the notebook containing important academic content that was supposed to be published next.
monologue: "Ha, Eilert Luo really got completely drunk at the event, he's really unreliable. He even lost the notebook with important academic content recorded in it."

memory: During the event, George Dai had to leave in a hurry due to an urgent matter and drove home, only to realize that Eilert Luo's notebook was left in his car. He handed Eilert Luo's notebook to Hedda Gai for safekeeping and then left.
monologue: George Dai found Eilert Luo's notebook in his car, handed it over to me for safekeeping, and then hurried out to run some errands.

memory: Thea Fu went to Hedda Gai's house to discuss a matter with Eilert Luo that required a decision to be made.
monologue: Thea Fu came to discuss decision-making matters with Eilert Luo, so she came to my house.

memory: Hedda Gai and Thea Fu exchanged pleasantries, but Thea Fu later opened up about her marital separation. She made it clear that she had no intention of returning to her husband. Hedda Gai was shocked by this revelation, as she believed maintaining appearances was important, especially considering that Thea Fu's husband was the chief of police and could potentially boost her campaign.
monologue: Thea Fu actually said she doesn't want to go back to her husband! She's a presidential candidate and needs to maintain a good image. How could she say such a thing? Besides, her husband is the chief of the police department, which is a great help to her campaign!

memory: Eilert Loe returned to Hedda Gabler's house in a drunken state, and Thea Elvsted was deeply disappointed to see him in such a condition. Eilert Loe then made some extreme remarks, confessing that he actually despised his current way of life and admitted that his research was nothing but a fraud.
monologue: Drunk Eilert Luo returned to my home, and seeing him in this intoxicated state, Thea Fu was extremely disappointed. Eilert Luo's emotions were out of control, and he even expressed that he hates his current way of life and believes that his research is all a sham!

memory: Eilert Luo lied and said that he had personally destroyed the notebook. Eilert Luo told Thea Fu to go back to her own husband. Thea Fu couldn't believe it and felt lost in life.
monologue: Eilert Luo actually lied that she destroyed the notebook by herself, and even demanded that Thea Fu go back to her husband! Being scolded by Eilert Luo in this way left Thea Fu incredulous.

memory: Hedda Gai just found out that Eilert Luo's second research was completed with Thea Fu, and Thea Fu was at least the second author.
monologue: I only just found out that Thea Fu and Eilert Luo completed the second research project together.

memory: The research completed by Eilert Luo and Thea Fu is not only an academic achievement for Eilert Luo or a political endorsement for Thea Fu, but also a demonstration of their own lifestyles. Through this research, Thea Fu proved her independence and ability, while Eilert Luo proved that he still has a future.
monologue: Eilert Luo and Thea Fu proudly call this research their brainchild, which serves as a testament to both of their value.

memory: Because they both contributed, Eilert Luo and Thea Fu coincidentally referred to the study as their own child. Hedda Gai was greatly shocked by Eilert Luo and Thea Fu's use of the term "child" to describe the research.
monologue: Eilert Luo and Thea Fu referring to that research project as their child truly shocked me. I can't understand why they would treat a research project as their own child; it's absolutely absurd. I have never seen such a ridiculous metaphor. Don't they realize it's just a job?

memory: Thea Fu, feeling disheartened, left Hedda Gai's home, leaving Eilert Loe and Hedda Gai alone in the house. Eilert Loe confided in Hedda Gai, expressing his deep disappointment in himself and the fact that Thea Fu is equally disappointed in him. He also revealed that he feels as if he has lost the research that was like a child to him. All of this has led Eilert Loe to believe that only a return to rock bottom awaits him, and that it would be better to end his own life sooner rather than later.
monologue: Thea Fu, whose research findings were destroyed, left my home in despair. It was just Eilert Luo and me left in the house. Eilert Luo confided in me that he was utterly disappointed in himself, feeling hopeless about his future without his research results, and even contemplating death as a better option.

memory: Hedda Gai handed her father's beloved pistol to Eilert Luo, confirming his intention to commit suicide. She told Eilert Luo that it's one thing not to want to live, but it's more important to leave behind a beautiful exit. Because Thea Fu is running for election and needs a good image, Eilert Luo's downfall can't afford to tarnish Thea Fu's campaign.
monologue: I handed over the handgun that my father used to Eilert Luo, affirming his desire to end his own life. After all, not wanting to live is one thing, but being able to die a heroic death is the most important. Because Thea Fu is running for election and needs a good image, Eilert Luo's downfall must not be allowed to affect Thea Fu's camp.

memory: Hedda Gai never revealed to Eilert Loe and Thea Fu the fact that she had the notebook in her possession. After Eilert Loe left her home, she burned his notebook.
monologue: I never told Eilert Luo and Thea Fu that I still had his notebook. After Eilert Luo left, I burned the notebook.

memory: Eilert Luo was found dead from suicide. When George Dai returned home, he anxiously told Hedda Gai, "Eilert Luo actually committed suicide."
monologue: Eilert Luo was found dead by suicide, and George Dai hurriedly told me the news when he came home.

memory: Hedda Gai is indifferent to George Dai's panic and feels that Eilert Luo truly lives up to her ideal, as he is decisive and ensures that everything turns out beautifully.
monologue: George Dai's panic is irrelevant to me, I only care that Eilert Luo's suicide aligns with my perception of him. I'm determined to act decisively, as long as the results are satisfying.

memory: George Dai remembered the notebook of Eilert Luo that he had entrusted to Hedda Gai for safekeeping. Hedda Gai then informed him that, for the sake of their future, for George Dai's academic standing, and for her own election, she had already burned Eilert Luo's notebook.
monologue: George Dai inquired about the notebook, to which I responded that in order to uphold George Dai's academic standing and my candidacy, I made the difficult decision to burn Eilert Luo's notebook.

memory: Hedda Gai deceived George Dai for the sake of their future, George Dai's academic position, and her own election.
monologue: I deceived George Dai by saying that burning the notebook was for the future of both of us, George Dai's academic status, and my own election.

memory: George Dai was deceived by Hedda Gai, believing that she destroyed the notebook solely for his sake, thinking that she loved him deeply. This instantly dispelled his previous feelings of insecurity. George Dai stated that since Hedda Gai was willing to go to such lengths for him, he decided to no longer concern himself with Eilert Luo's notebook.
monologue: Haha, George Dai really believed that I burned Eilert Luo's notebook out of love between us. But it's okay, he has also decided to stop worrying about this matter.

memory: The news of Eilert Luo's suicide has been widely reported. Thea Fu has issued an official statement announcing her intention to continue running for office, but she has not commented much on the event and has not made any public appearances.
monologue: The news of Eilert Luo's suicide has caused a sensation in the media. Thea Fu has stated that she will continue running for election, but has not elaborated further.

memory: Hedda Gai has decided to hold a press conference regarding Eilert Luo's suicide, and will be accompanied by George Dai.
monologue: I have decided to hold a press conference to mourn the passing of Eilert Luo.

memory: Hedda Gai wants to create an image of marital unity, highlighting the stark contrast between herself and Thea Fu's chaotic camp.
monologue: I want to use the press conference as an opportunity to create an image of unity between my husband George and I, and to highlight the stark contrast between myself and the chaotic camp of Thea Fu.

memory: Hedda Gai has scheduled a press conference for 11:00 a.m. this morning.
monologue: The press conference is about to start, and I'm in the green room with George Dai, getting ready for the press conference.
